Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Recent advances in sensor technologies and expansion of wired and
wireless communication protocols enable us to continuously collect
information about the physical world, resulting in a rich set of novel
services. The ability to infer relevant patterns from these event
streams in real-time and at various levels of abstractions to make
near instantaneous decisions is crucial for a wide range of mission
critical applications ranging from real-time crisis management to
security. This project designs, implements, and evaluates a novel
complex event processing methodology, henceforth called Complex Event
Analytics (CEA). CEA integrates the capabilities of pattern matching
from complex event processing with the power of multi-level analysis
from static OLAP engines to provide multi-dimensional sequential
pattern analysis over high-speed event streams. The CEA Model
combines CEP and OLAP techniques for efficient multi-dimensional event
pattern analysis at different abstraction levels. Based on
interrelationships in both concept and pattern refinement among
queries, sequence queries are composed into an integrated event
pattern hierarchy. OLAP like operations enable analysts to navigate
from one E-cuboid to another in this event analytics space. CEA
optimization strategies, including rewriting rules, physical
operators, and cost-based search algorithms, achieve scalable event
processing. CEA offers high-performance analytics by maximal shared
processing of event pattern queries. Experimental studies compare the
CEA solution to the state-of-the-art, including traditional stream
query systems and customized event engines. Intellectual merit lies
in the design, development and evaluation of a novel Complex Event
Analytics technology for real-time event stream analysis, -- a perfect
middle ground offering both the sophisticated power of pattern
matching found in modern event processing systems and the capability
of online analytic techniques at multiple levels of abstraction of
OLAP engines. CEA impacts society by facilitating a broad range of
stream-centric applications ranging from monitoring of hygiene
compliance to prevent the spread of infectuous diseases in medical
settings to business intelligence processing, and by integrating
project activities with education.

For further information see the project web site at the URL:
http://davis.wpi.edu/dsrg/PROJECTS/CEA

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Advances in sensor technologies and expansion of wired and wireless communication protocols enable us to continuously collect information about the physical world, resulting in a rich set of novelservices. Outpatient care, real-time crisis management, supply chain management, and security are all domains in which this wealth of information aids in the detection and tracking of events and phenomena. The ability to infer relevant patterns from these event streams in real-time and at various levels of abstractions to make near instantaneous decisions is crucial for a wide range of mission critical applications ranging from real-time crisis management to security. This project designs, implements, and evaluates a novelcomplex event processing methodology, henceforth called Complex EventAnalytics (CEA). CEA integrates the capabilities of pattern matching from complex event processing with the power of multi-level analysis from static OLAP engines to provide multi-dimensional sequential pattern analysis over high-speed event streams.

COMPLEX EVENT ANALYTICS MODELING INNOVATION.  The first TECHNICAL MERIT  is the CEA Model, which innovatively combines CEP and OLAP techniques for efficient multi-dimensional event pattern analysis at different abstraction levels.  Based on interrelationships in both concept and pattern refinement among queries, sequence queries are composed into an integrated event pattern hierarchy. OLAP-like operations enable analysts to navigate from one E-cuboid to another in this event analytics space.

COMPLEX EVENT ANALYTICS OPTIMIZATION.  Technical contributions in the area of optimization specific for complex event processing also are achieved by this project. These optimization strategies include methods to for the first time push aggregation into the sequence construction process. Other innovative CEA optimization strategies, including event pattern rewriting rules, pattern sharing methods and cost-based strategies algorithms, produce scalable event processing execution plans.

HIGH PERFORMANCE EVENT ANALYTICS EXECUTION INNOVATION. To handle workloads composed of huge numbers of pattern queries concurrently, our executor maximally shares the processing of multiple event pattern queries exploiting the concept and the pattern refinement relationships between queries for reuse. The scalable, principled execution solution determines not only what to share from sequence subpattern to aggregation but also whether to share or not.  This innovation renders event analytics execution performance practically viable.

REACTIVE EVENT ANALYTICS AND OTHER ADVANCED FEATURES.  To support actions triggered by the detection of complex events, including the update of variables, the CEA execution infrastructure includes a CEPcustomized stream transaction model along with novel scheduling policies for correctly managing their execution even under concurrent updating. Other services include the preservation of privacy under CEP pattern processing.

PERFORMANCE EVALUATION USING REAL WORLD DATA. Experimental studies are conducted to compare the Complex Event Analytics solution tostate-of-theB, art strategies, including traditional stream query systems and customized event processing engines. Superiority of the CEA technology often by many orders of magnitude is demonstrated.

APPLICATIONS WITH HIGH SOCIETAL IMPACT. CEA impacts society by facilitating abroad range of stream-centric applications ranging from medicine,business intelligence to engineering. One example of this broaderimpact concerns the collaborative effort with the UMass MedicalCenter. In this real-world case study, our CEA technology is packaged into a system, called HyReminder, and applied to solve a problem of major societal impact. This includes the monitoring of hygiene compliance toprevent the spread of infectious diseases in intensive ...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Advances in sensor technologies and expansion of wired and wireless communication protocols enable us to continuously collect information about the physical world, resulting in a rich set of novelservices. Outpatient care, real-time crisis management, supply chain management, and security are all domains in which this wealth of information aids in the detection and tracking of events and phenomena. The ability to infer relevant patterns from these event streams in real-time and at various levels of abstractions to make near instantaneous decisions is crucial for a wide range of mission critical applications ranging from real-time crisis management to security. This project designs, implements, and evaluates a novelcomplex event processing methodology, henceforth called Complex EventAnalytics (CEA). CEA integrates the capabilities of pattern matching from complex event processing with the power of multi-level analysis from static OLAP engines to provide multi-dimensional sequential pattern analysis over high-speed event streams. COMPLEX EVENT ANALYTICS MODELING INNOVATION. The first TECHNICAL MERIT is the CEA Model, which innovatively combines CEP and OLAP techniques for efficient multi-dimensional event pattern analysis at different abstraction levels. Based on interrelationships in both concept and pattern refinement among queries, sequence queries are composed into an integrated event pattern hierarchy. OLAP-like operations enable analysts to navigate from one E-cuboid to another in this event analytics space. COMPLEX EVENT ANALYTICS OPTIMIZATION. Technical contributions in the area of optimization specific for complex event processing also are achieved by this project. These optimization strategies include methods to for the first time push aggregation into the sequence construction process. Other innovative CEA optimization strategies, including event pattern rewriting rules, pattern sharing methods and cost-based strategies algorithms, produce scalable event processing execution plans. HIGH PERFORMANCE EVENT ANALYTICS EXECUTION INNOVATION. To handle workloads composed of huge numbers of pattern queries concurrently, our executor maximally shares the processing of multiple event pattern queries exploiting the concept and the pattern refinement relationships between queries for reuse. The scalable, principled execution solution determines not only what to share from sequence subpattern to aggregation but also whether to share or not. This innovation renders event analytics execution performance practically viable. REACTIVE EVENT ANALYTICS AND OTHER ADVANCED FEATURES. To support actions triggered by the detection of complex events, including the update of variables, the CEA execution infrastructure includes a CEPcustomized stream transaction model along with novel scheduling policies for correctly managing their execution even under concurrent updating. Other services include the preservation of privacy under CEP pattern processing. PERFORMANCE EVALUATION USING REAL WORLD DATA. Experimental studies are conducted to compare the Complex Event Analytics solution tostate-of-theB, art strategies, including traditional stream query systems and customized event processing engines. Superiority of the CEA technology often by many orders of magnitude is demonstrated. APPLICATIONS WITH HIGH SOCIETAL IMPACT. CEA impacts society by facilitating abroad range of stream-centric applications ranging from medicine,business intelligence to engineering. One example of this broaderimpact concerns the collaborative effort with the UMass MedicalCenter. In this real-world case study, our CEA technology is packaged into a system, called HyReminder, and applied to solve a problem of major societal impact. This includes the monitoring of hygiene compliance toprevent the spread of infectious diseases in intensive care units byin real-time analyzing events from sensors deployed across the intensive care units at the UMASS Memorial hospital....
